ground_truth: The flashback ends. Mickey is back in the present in his darkened living room, illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch. A coffee table sits in front of the couch, and papers are scattered on the floor. Mickey gets up from the couch where he'd been sitting and paces back and forth as he talks over the screen. Manon Lescaut is being performed. Onstage, the soprano in the title role sings a mournful aria as she kneels by the ruins of a wagon; the background is dark. The film moves up to the private boxes in the upper loge, where David and Holly can be seen from a distance sitting in one of the boxes. David glances at her; he reaches down for a bottle of wine. The movie briefly cuts back to the stage, where the soprano is leaning on a wagon wheel; her voice soars. Then it's back to a closer look at Holly and David in their box. The aria continues as David hands a smiling Holly a glass. He uncorks the wine and pours some in both their glasses. Holly mouths a thank you, glancing around. They look at each other and raise their glasses in a toast. Lee, wearing a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, has opened the door for Elliot and his client, wealthy rock star Dusty Frye. Lee closes the door behind the men and walks over to Dusty. Lee chuckles as she looks at him; he is wearing sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a baggy coat. She turns and walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty farther into the loft, her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick covers his face to hide his disgust. As Dusty talks, the camera follows Elliot, who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel. Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings, then surreptitiously at Lee, admiring her body as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera leaves Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and starts leading him to the door. Frederick follows at a distance. The camera now moves back to Elliot, still staring at the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee. He laughs. Lee, uneasy, looks down. There's an awkward moment of silence. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable. The record in place, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The recollection concludes. Mickey is returned in the current in his dimmed sitting room, lit by a glow from a casement behind the sofa. A coffee table rests in front of the sofa, and documents are strewn on the ground. Mickey rises from the sofa where he'd been resting and strides back and forth as he speaks over the display. Manon Lescaut is being enacted. Onstage, the soprano in the titular role sings a sorrowful aria as she kneels by the remnants of a carriage; the background is dim. The film shifts up to the private enclosures in the upper tier, where David and Holly can be observed from a distance seated in one of the enclosures. David glances at her; he reaches down for a bottle of wine. The movie briefly switches back to the stage, where the soprano is leaning on a carriage wheel; her voice ascends. Then it's back to a closer view of Holly and David in their enclosure. The aria persists as David hands a grinning Holly a glass. He uncorks the wine and pours some in both their glasses. Holly mouths a thank you, glancing around. They look at each other and lift their glasses in a salute. Lee, wearing a loose plaid shirt and jeans, has opened the door for Elliot and his client, affluent rock star Dusty Frye. Lee closes the door behind the men and walks over to Dusty. Lee chuckles as she looks at him; he is wearing sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a loose coat. She turns and walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty farther into the loft, her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick covers his face to conceal his disgust. As Dusty talks, the camera follows Elliot, who walks past the others to scrutinize the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel. Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings, then covertly at Lee, admiring her figure as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera leaves Elliot to follow the eager Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and starts leading him to the door. Frederick follows at a distance. The camera now moves back to Elliot, still staring at the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee. He laughs. Lee, uneasy, looks down. There's an awkward moment of silence. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf. She pulls the record out of its sleeve and places it on the turntable. The record in place, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The flashback is ended. The present is returned to by Mickey in his darkened living room, illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch. In front of the couch sits a coffee table, and the floor is scattered with papers. The couch, where he'd been sitting, is exited by Mickey, and back and forth pacing is begun by him as he talks over the screen. Manon Lescaut is performed. The soprano in the title role sings a mournful aria onstage as a wagon's ruins are knelt by her; the background is dark. The private boxes in the upper loge, where David and Holly are seen from a distance sitting in one of the boxes, are moved up to by the film. A glance is given to her by David; a bottle of wine is reached down for by him. The stage, where a wagon wheel is leaned on by the soprano, is briefly cut back to by the movie; her voice is soared. Then David and Holly are looked at more closely in their box. The aria is continued as a glass is handed to a smiling Holly by David. Some wine is uncorked and poured by him into both their glasses. A thank you is mouthed by Holly, glancing around. Each other is looked at by them and their glasses are raised in a toast. The door is opened by Lee, wearing a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, for Elliot and his client, wealthy rock star Dusty Frye. The door is closed behind the men by Lee and Dusty is walked over to. A chuckle is given by Lee as she looks at him; sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a baggy coat are worn by him. She and Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty are walked farther into the loft, her hands clasped behind her back. His face is covered by Frederick to hide his disgust. While Dusty talks, Elliot is followed by the camera, who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely. On an easel are propped up two framed nude drawings of Lee. The drawings are glanced at admiringly by Elliot, then Lee is surreptitiously glanced at, admiring her body as an offscreen Dusty and Frederick are conversed with by her. Elliot is left by the camera to follow the enthusiastic Lee as Dusty is taken by the arm and is started to be led to the door. At a distance, Frederick follows. Elliot, who is still staring at the nude drawings, is moved back to by the camera, as Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. An offscreen Lee is turned to and hesitantly smiled at by him. Laughter is given by him. Uneasiness is shown by Lee as she looks down. There is an awkward moment of silence. Lee is followed by the camera as she walks quickly to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf. The record is pulled out of its jacket and put on the turntable by her. With the record in place, Lee is turned and leaned back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Mickey returns to the present, sitting in his dim living room, lit by glow from a window behind the couch. Papers are scattered on the floor near a coffee table. He gets up and paces, speaking as *Manon Lescaut* plays. Onstage, the soprano kneels by a ruined wagon, singing mournfully in a dark setting. The film shifts to a private box where David and Holly sit. David glances at her, then grabs a wine bottle. The scene briefly returns to the soprano leaning on a wagon wheel, her voice soaring, before cutting back to David handing Holly a glass. He pours wine, and they toast. Lee, in a plaid shirt and jeans, opens the door for Elliot and wealthy rock star Dusty Frye. Dusty wears sunglasses, a red T-shirt, and a baggy coat. Lee chuckles and walks with them, hands behind her back. Frederick hides his disgust. As Dusty talks, Elliot examines two framed nude drawings of Lee. He admires them, then glances at Lee. Lee, enthusiastic, takes Dusty by the arm toward the door, followed by Frederick. The camera lingers on Elliot staring at the drawings. As footsteps fade, he turns and smiles at offscreen Lee. He laughs; she looks down, uneasy. After a silence, she walks to the stereo, pulls a record, places it on the turntable, then leans back against the unit.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The flashback ends. Mickey is in his dim living room, lit by a window glow. Papers are scattered on the floor near a coffee table. He paces while talking over the screen. Manon Lescaut is performed onstage; the soprano sings a mournful aria by a wagon's ruins. The film shifts to the upper loge, showing David and Holly in a box. David glances at her, reaches for wine, and pours it. Holly mouths thanks, and they toast. Lee, in a plaid shirt and jeans, opens the door for Elliot and rock star Dusty Frye. Lee chuckles at Dusty's sunglasses, T-shirt, and coat. She walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty into the loft. Frederick hides his disgust. Elliot examines two framed nude drawings of Lee, admiring them and her. Lee enthusiastically leads Dusty to the door, with Frederick following. Elliot, still staring at the drawings, smiles at an offscreen Lee. He laughs, and Lee looks down uneasily. After an awkward silence, Lee quickly goes to the stereo, puts a record on, and leans against the unit.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The flashback concludes, bringing Mickey back to the present moment, where he finds himself in his dimly lit living room. The room is softly illuminated by a gentle glow filtering through a window situated behind the couch. In front of the couch, a coffee table stands, and the floor is littered with scattered papers. Mickey rises from the couch, where he had been seated, and begins to pace back and forth, speaking aloud as he moves across the screen. Meanwhile, the opera "Manon Lescaut" is being performed. Onstage, the soprano, portraying the title role, sings a deeply mournful aria while kneeling beside the ruins of a wagon; the background is shrouded in darkness. The film transitions to the private boxes located in the upper loge, where David and Holly are visible from a distance, seated together in one of the boxes. David casts a glance at Holly and reaches down to retrieve a bottle of wine. The movie briefly cuts back to the stage, where the soprano leans on a wagon wheel, her voice soaring with emotion. Then, the focus returns to a closer view of Holly and David in their box. The aria continues to play as David hands a smiling Holly a glass. He uncorks the wine and pours some into both of their glasses. Holly mouths a silent thank you, glancing around the surroundings. They exchange looks and raise their glasses in a toast. Meanwhile, Lee, dressed in a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, opens the door for Elliot and his client, the wealthy rock star Dusty Frye. Lee closes the door behind the men and approaches Dusty. She chuckles as she observes him; he is wearing sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a baggy coat. She turns and walks alongside Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty, moving farther into the loft with her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick covers his face, attempting to conceal his disgust. As Dusty speaks, the camera follows Elliot, who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel. Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings, then surreptitiously at Lee, appreciating her form as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera shifts focus from Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and begins leading him toward the door. Frederick follows at a distance. The camera then returns to Elliot, who is still intently staring at the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard departing the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles at an offscreen Lee. He laughs softly. Lee, feeling uneasy, looks down. An awkward moment of silence ensues. The camera follows Lee as she quickly walks to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf. She removes the record from its jacket and places it on the turntable. With the record in place, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The vivid flashback sequence draws to its natural conclusion, gently guiding Mickey back to the present reality of his dimly lit living room, a familiar and somewhat somber setting. The room is softly illuminated by a gentle, almost ethereal glow that filters through a window situated directly behind the couch, casting a subtle light across the space. In front of the couch, which serves as a central piece of furniture, stands a modest coffee table. The floor around this area is cluttered with scattered papers, illustrating a sense of disarray. Mickey, who had been seated on the couch in a state of contemplation, rises to his feet and begins to pace back and forth. As he moves deliberately across the screen, he speaks aloud, voicing his thoughts. Meanwhile, in a parallel scene, the opera "Manon Lescaut" is being performed with great passion. Onstage, the talented soprano, portraying the title role with dramatic flair, sings a deeply mournful aria. She is positioned on her knees beside the ruins of a wagon, and the background is effectively shrouded in shadowy darkness, adding to the poignant mood. 

The film transitions seamlessly to the private boxes located in the prestigious upper loge, capturing a distant view of David and Holly, who are comfortably seated together in one of these exclusive boxes. David casts a thoughtful glance at Holly and proceeds to reach down, retrieving a bottle of wine with a graceful motion. The movie then briefly cuts back to the stage, capturing a poignant moment as the soprano, with her voice soaring with heartfelt emotion, leans on a wagon wheel. The cinematic focus then returns to offer a closer view of Holly and David in their box. The aria continues to enchant the audience as David, with a gentle smile, hands Holly a glass. He skillfully uncorks the bottle of wine and pours an amount into both of their waiting glasses. Holly mouths a silent expression of gratitude, her eyes scanning the surroundings. They share an intimate exchange of glances and raise their glasses in a celebratory toast.

Meanwhile, in a contrasting scene, Lee, casually dressed in a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, opens the door for Elliot and his client, the affluent rock star Dusty Frye. Lee closes the door behind the men and approaches Dusty, chuckling as she observes him in his eccentric attire—he wears sunglasses, a striking red-imprinted T-shirt, and a roomy coat. She gracefully turns, walking alongside Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty, moving deeper into the spacious loft with her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick, trying to maintain composure, covers his face in an attempt to conceal his evident disgust. As Dusty speaks animatedly, the camera carefully follows Elliot, who walks purposefully past the others to examine the artful drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up impressively on an easel, capturing attention. Elliot glances with admiration at the drawings, then discreetly at Lee, appreciating her form as she converses animatedly with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick.

The camera shifts focus, transitioning from Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and initiates leading him toward the door. Frederick follows at a respectful distance. In a fluid motion, the camera then returns to capture Elliot, who remains intently fascinated by the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's departing footsteps echo throughout the loft. He turns, hesitantly offering a subdued smile toward an offscreen Lee, and laughs softly, a sound filled with subtle meaning. Lee, feeling a sense of awkwardness, looks down, a gesture laden with emotion. An uncomfortable moment of silence hangs in the air. The camera follows Lee as she quickly walks with purpose to the stereo unit, removing a record from the shelf. She carefully extracts the record from its jacket and places it onto the turntable. With the record now in place, Lee turns and casually leans back against the stereo unit, a figure of composed elegance.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The flashback concludes, and Mickey finds himself back in the present, seated in his dimly lit living room, where the only illumination comes from a soft glow filtering through a window positioned behind the couch. In front of him, a coffee table stands, while papers lie scattered across the floor, creating a sense of disarray. Rising from the couch where he had been sitting, Mickey begins to pace back and forth, his movements deliberate as he talks over the screen. Meanwhile, the opera "Manon Lescaut" is being performed, and onstage, the soprano, embodying the title role, sings a mournful aria, her voice filled with emotion as she kneels beside the ruins of a wagon, the dark background enhancing the somber mood. The film transitions to the private boxes in the upper loge, offering a distant view of David and Holly seated together in one of the boxes. David, casting a glance at Holly, reaches down to retrieve a bottle of wine. The scene briefly shifts back to the stage, capturing the soprano as she leans on a wagon wheel, her voice soaring with intensity. The focus then returns to a closer view of Holly and David in their box, where the aria continues to play. David hands a smiling Holly a glass, uncorks the wine, and pours it into both their glasses. Holly mouths a silent thank you, her eyes darting around the room. They exchange a look, their eyes meeting as they raise their glasses in a toast. In another setting, Lee, dressed in a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, opens the door to welcome Elliot and his client, the wealthy rock star Dusty Frye. After they enter, Lee closes the door behind them and approaches Dusty, chuckling as she takes in his appearance, which includes sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a baggy coat. She then turns and walks alongside Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty, her hands clasped behind her back as they move deeper into the loft. Frederick, meanwhile, covers his face, attempting to conceal his disgust. As Dusty speaks, the camera tracks Elliot, who moves past the group to examine the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel, and Elliot glances at them with admiration before casting a surreptitious look at Lee, appreciating her form as she engages in conversation with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera shifts focus from Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee, who takes Dusty by the arm and begins to lead him toward the door, with Frederick trailing at a distance. The camera then returns to Elliot, who remains fixated on the nude drawings, as the sound of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps echoes, signaling their departure from the loft. Elliot turns, offering a hesitant smile to an offscreen Lee, and lets out a laugh. Lee, feeling uneasy, lowers her gaze, and an awkward silence ensues. The camera follows Lee as she swiftly moves to the stereo unit, selecting a record from the shelf. She carefully removes the record from its jacket and places it on the turntable. With the record set, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit, her posture reflecting a mix of contemplation and resolve.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
The flashback ends, and Mickey finds himself back in his dimly lit living room, illuminated by a window's glow. Papers are scattered on the floor around the coffee table. Rising from the couch, he paces while speaking over the screen. Meanwhile, "Manon Lescaut" is being performed onstage, with the soprano singing a mournful aria by a wagon's ruins. The scene shifts to the upper loge, where David and Holly sit in a private box. David glances at Holly, retrieves a wine bottle, and pours them both a glass. They exchange a smile, mouth a thank you, and toast each other as the aria continues. 

Elsewhere, Lee, in a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, welcomes Elliot and his client, rock star Dusty Frye, into the loft. She closes the door and approaches Dusty, who is dressed in sunglasses, a red T-shirt, and a baggy coat. Lee walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty further into the loft, while Frederick hides his disgust. As Dusty talks, Elliot examines two framed nude drawings of Lee on an easel, admiring both the art and Lee herself. Lee enthusiastically takes Dusty by the arm, leading him to the door with Frederick following. The camera returns to Elliot, who continues to admire the drawings as Frederick and Dusty leave. He turns, hesitantly smiles at Lee, and laughs, creating an awkward silence. Lee, feeling uneasy, quickly moves to the stereo, selects a record, and places it on the turntable before leaning back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The flashback ends. Mickey is back in the present in his darkened living room, illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch. This window overlooks the bustling city streets of New York, known for its vibrant nightlife. A coffee table sits in front of the couch, and papers are scattered on the floor. These papers are remnants of his work as an investigative journalist, often leaving behind a clutter of notes and articles. Mickey gets up from the couch where he'd been sitting and paces back and forth as he talks over the screen. Manon Lescaut, an opera composed by Giacomo Puccini in 1893, is being performed. Onstage, the soprano in the title role sings a mournful aria as she kneels by the ruins of a wagon; the background is dark. The film moves up to the private boxes in the upper loge, an exclusive seating area typically reserved for patrons and special guests, where David and Holly can be seen from a distance sitting in one of the boxes. David glances at her; he reaches down for a bottle of wine, a vintage Bordeaux known for its rich, full-bodied flavor. The movie briefly cuts back to the stage, where the soprano is leaning on a wagon wheel; her voice soars. Then it's back to a closer look at Holly and David in their box. The aria continues as David hands a smiling Holly a glass. He uncorks the wine, a ritual often associated with celebratory occasions, and pours some in both their glasses. Holly mouths a thank you, glancing around at the opulent surroundings of the theater. They look at each other and raise their glasses in a toast. Lee, wearing a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, has opened the door for Elliot and his client, wealthy rock star Dusty Frye, whose latest album topped the charts. Lee closes the door behind the men and walks over to Dusty. Lee chuckles as she looks at him; he is wearing sunglasses, a red-imprinted T-shirt featuring his band's logo, and a baggy coat. She turns and walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty farther into the loft, her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick covers his face to hide his disgust, possibly at Dusty's eccentric fashion choices. As Dusty talks, the camera follows Elliot, who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee, captured in pencil with delicate shading, are propped up on an easel. Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings, then surreptitiously at Lee, admiring her body as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera leaves Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and starts leading him to the door, reminder of their brief yet professional business encounter. Frederick follows at a distance. The camera now moves back to Elliot, still staring at the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee, aware of the vulnerability the artwork exposes. He laughs. Lee, uneasy, looks down, feeling the weight of Elliot's gaze. There's an awkward moment of silence. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf, a rare jazz collection she often plays to ease tension. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable. The record in place, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. Lee closes the door behind the men and walks over to Dusty. Lee chuckles as she looks at him. he is wearing sunglasses a redimprinted Tshirt and a baggy coat. She turns and walks with Frederick Elliot and Dusty farther into the loft her hands clasped behind her back. Frederick covers his face to hide his disgust. As Dusty talks the camera follows Elliot who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely. Two framed nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel. Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings then surreptitiously at Lee admiring her body as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick. The camera leaves Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee as she takes Dusty by the arm and starts leading him to the door. Frederick follows at a distance. The camera now moves back to Elliot still staring at the nude drawings. as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee. He laughs. Lee uneasy looks down. There is an awkward moment of silence. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit pulling a record off the shelf. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable. The record in place. Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: The flashback ends. Mickey is back in the present in his darkened living room illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch. A coffee table sits in front of the couch and papers are scattered on the floor. Mickey gets up from the couch where he would been sitting and paces back and forth as he talks over the screen. Manon Lescaut is being performed. Onstage. the soprano in the title role sings a mournful aria as she kneels by the ruins of a wagon. the background is dark. The film moves up to the private boxes in the upper loge where David and Holly can be seen from a distance. sitting in one of the boxes. The camera now moves back to Elliot still staring at the nude drawings. as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft. He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee. He laughs. Lee uneasy looks down. There is an awkward moment of silence. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit pulling a record off the shelf. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable. The record in place. Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: The flashback ends. Mickey is back in the present in his darkened living room illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch. A coffee table sits in front of the couch and papers are scattered on the floor. Mickey gets up from the couch where he would been sitting and paces back and forth as he talks over the screen. The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit pulling a record off the shelf. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable. The record in place. Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The recollection concludes. Rufus is now in the future in his brightly lit garage, illuminated by a beam from a skylight above the bench. A bookshelf sits beside the bench, and marbles are scattered on the carpet. Rufus leaps up from the bench where he'd been lounging and jogs side to side as he mumbles throughout the street. Figaro's Adventure is being painted. Offstage, the tenor in the lead part draws a cheerful sketch as he stands by the remnants of a sailboat; the foreground is bright. The picture zooms up to the shared platforms in the lower loge, where Sarah and Charlie can be spotted from afar resting on one of the platforms. Sarah peers at him; she bends over for a can of soda. The video momentarily shifts back to the painting, where the tenor is balancing on a boat anchor; his fingers dance. Then it returns to a closer shot of Charlie and Sarah in their platform. The sketch persists as Charlie passes a grinning Sarah a pencil. He cracks open the soda and pours some in both their cups. Sarah whispers an appreciation, scanning the area. They gaze at each other and clink their cups in a gesture. Max, wearing a slim polka-dot cardigan and shorts, has swung open the gate for Jordan and his passenger, affluent disco legend Echo Blaze. Max latches the gate behind the folks and skips over to Echo. Max giggles as he observes her; she is wearing a visor, a blue-striped jersey, and a fitted blazer. She spins and skips with Lily, Jordan, and Echo deeper into the den, her fingers clasped in front of her waist. Lily shields her eyes to conceal her boredom. As Echo jokes, the lens trails Jordan, who skips beyond the rest to admire the sculptures more nearly. Two framed ceramic sculptures of Max are propped up on a pedestal. Jordan peeks approvingly at the sculptures, then slyly at Max, admiring her frame as she banters with an invisible Echo and Lily. The lens departs from Jordan to trail the energetic Max as she takes Echo by the hand and begins guiding her to the gate. Lily follows from afar. The lens now swings back to Jordan, still gawking at the ceramic sculptures, as the noises of Lily's and Echo's footsteps echo exiting the den. He pivots and sheepishly beams to an invisible Max. He chuckles. Max, tense, glances up. There's a clumsy gap of quiet. The lens trails Max as she hurries to the bookshelf, extracting a book off the rack. She extracts the book from its sleeve and places it on the podium. The book in position, Max rotates and reclines against the bookshelf.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The flashback ends, and Mickey finds himself in his dim living room, pacing as the opera "Manon Lescaut" plays in the background. Onstage, the soprano performs a mournful aria, shifting to the private boxes where David and Holly sit. David pours wine, and they toast, exchanging smiles. Meanwhile, Lee welcomes Elliot and his client, rock star Dusty Frye, into the loft. Dusty, dressed in sunglasses and a casual outfit, chats as Elliot admires framed nude drawings of Lee. Lee eagerly leads Dusty to the door, with Frederick slow to follow. Elliot, captivated by the drawings, hesitantly smiles at Lee. Feeling awkward, Lee turns to put a record on the stereo and leans back against it, ending the tense moment.
